33111885.review: Wuppo was an adorable, original, and fun adventure game that is a strong rec. It reminded me a lot of Yoshi's Island and other great SNES games. It's story-heavy and character-heavy, with a super-cute art style and I really just loved it. It's genuinely one of the most heartfelt games of its type I've encountered in these sales -- when so many games feel like exersizes in bland, emotionless mediocrity, Wuppo clearly was made with a lot of love, and it shows. I also thought it hit that sweet spot of being challenging and requiring quick thinking, but never getting frustrating. It also (also) feels finished, while a lot of these games feel like they rush to wrap up because the dev ran out of time/resources, Wuppo is very much finished and feels finished, and even has an extra area that's totally optional but has some lore. Spill the ice cream, save the world!

33050270.review:
This game is a rare 10/10 from me. I will heap praise upon it for days because it's a unique experience, unlike anything else I've played. It's also a very clever and insightful game, the world and mechanics constantly surprise and impress me. The story is rivetting, the gameplay is tough and satifying, the progression is meaningful. The world is full of endless secrets, surprises and fascinating subplots to explore and characters to meet. Most of all, despite its unassuming appearance, Wuppo feels like a real, living world. Like a microcosm of the earth, complete with separate populations, nations, war, intrigue and politics. You begin as a simple face in the crowd (in fact it's easy to become literally lost in the crowd, to forget which little guy is you among the hundreds of onscreen characters) but over time you work with or against the various parties, tribes, nobles, organisations and gods to make the world a better place.
It would be difficult to play this game without immediately falling in love with the strange and charming world of Wuppo. If you like your games as a plain single scoop of vanilla then perhaps you'll be turned away, and some may find the combat/platforming too difficult. Some younger players may also be confused or overwhelmed by it all. But otherwise I can't recommend it highly enough. Do yourself a favour: grab your best hat or favourite object, wear it on your head, take off your seatbelt (and your trousers) and dive right in to the world of Wuppo, it's a truly priceless experience!

Wuppo是我一开始看了谜叔的视频感觉挺有趣的，画风和音乐也比较喜欢就买了的，玩了之后在不断的探险、战斗、解谜，以及与各种角色对话的过程中让我感觉到这个世界里的生物都是活生生的，你能不断跳下悬崖来逗你的同伴鹦鹉，还能在火车到站后等好长时间才下车让列车长生气，也可以在澡堂里悠闲的泡澡度过一天，另外游戏里还有17个Boss等待你去挑战，再加上许多的收集要素，这些都使得游玩的过程十分开心。
制作组的不断更新也让游戏变得更加有趣了，比较大的更新有去年年底加入了Boss Run模式让玩家可以竞争全球排行榜，还有最近出了简单模式让像我一样手残的人也可以不吃药打死最终boss了；小的更新有之前的版本里有一个角色说他在做一款小游戏，然后会让你试玩一下，在你刚要玩的时候那个小游戏就会显示error玩不了，可在前几个月的更新后居然就可以玩了，虽然只是个简单的射击类小游戏；另外制作组也很关心玩家的意见，当玩家发现有bug告诉制作组之后不用几天他们就一定会进行修复，之前还看到有个玩家在社区论坛里说他掉档了，制作组立马就说可以帮他做一个和他游戏进度差不多的存档，这些事情都让人感觉不管是游戏还是制作组都很让人暖心。
最后说下购买的建议吧，只想玩游戏的话只用买本体就可以了，Shop DLC是会在游戏里增加两个卖24顶专属帽子、几个可以改变身体颜色的食物、两个可以改变子弹颜色的东西和一把电力武器的商店，对游戏没有多大影响，Fun Pack是几张壁纸还有一个小设定集，最近还加进去了一个Wuppo世界是如何诞生的小视频，Soundtruck是音乐集就不用说了。

32618063.review:
It's difficult to describe Wuppo. Essentially you're a white fluff ball trying to save the world with a Gumgumgun. It is a unique and entertaining 2D RPG.

[h1]Positive:[/h1]
- Quirky but great art style and music.
- Love the small details, like how certain words shake or are bold when an NPC speaks (for emphasis or emotion) or that you can't cut the line at the amusement park.
- This game does not hold you by the hand. There are no arrows telling you were to go. No quest log. No map. You have to figure things out by yourself. Talk to NPCs, read what they say.
- So many side-quests and little interactions. This game really rewards you for exploring.
- Filmstrips will give you more background information about their world. If you're not interested, you don't have to watch them.
- Bosses can be challenging. You really need to learn their patterns.
- Every death is fair. You need to dodge those projectiles or position yourself properly. Get good, scrub.
- I love that the NPCs are active. They're constantly running around, changing hats, buying items/food.
- Shoutout to the Dutch developers who sneaked in Dutch words into their game. Big respect.
- Your happiness is important.
- Boss run is hard and shows you no mercy.
- Large number of items, hats, consumables.

[h1]Negative:[/h1]
- I came across some bugs. Nothing game breaking.
- Waiting for the train and trams can be boring (but the NPCs have places to go too, the world doesn't revolve around you).
- I would have liked to have a map.

[h1]Conclusion:[/h1]
Wuppo feels like a testament to older games: (1) you're expected to figure things out by yourself, (2) if you die, it's your own fault. I love it that the developers decided to create their game in this way. I'm sure that not everyone will feel this way but I really enjoyed Wuppo.

32535955.review:
Wuppo:
~~~~~~

Who would have believed that eating ice cream could earn you an eviction notice? Well, to be fair with Carlo, the Wum at the Wum House service desk, it’s not fun at all cleaning ice cream off the beautiful rugs at the entrance and on the fourth level. Especially now, when all the cleaners have run away to Popocity. It’s only part of the reason; the real reason is that Carlo dislikes cleaning (I’m with you, Carlo), but throwing a Wum out of the Wum House for this, it’s a tad extreme. Hey Wuppo! Did you hear what I say? You have to find a new place to live. Well, start cracking!

Wuppo is a platformer/adventure game with good puzzles where you control a cute, round character who has four legs and can make great double jumps. He is part of the Wum race, who are the most intelligent of four main species in the world, but lack of abilities.  The other three races are the Blussers, Splenkhakkers and the nasty Fnakkers. 

You’ll meet a bird, “Denksnavel,” fairly quickly in the game. This bird will give you hints every time you select him. The Allesweters is another character who you will be talking a fair bit with and can be found in different locations. He has a projector and can play the filmstrips collectable items you’ll find within the world. 

The world is extremely well-designed with great locations to discover, and it’s not hard to navigate. Within the main places, you’ll have to help other Wums or species to move forward in the game. Some will be challenging puzzles and others will lead to a fight with big, scary monsters! Please don’t scare the kawum out of me! When you successfully help these characters and make them happy, you’ll be rewarded with extra health points and items which in turn will help you to resolve the next puzzle or challenges in the world. There is a fair bit of reading in this game and you really need to take your time to go through it or you will miss important information. Bear in mind that you can come back to individuals and re-asked questions. The dialogue is really fun and you can select different answers when you interact with each creature.  
In some of the destinations, you’ll find stores where you can buy or sell items using the smurt currency. You can obtain additional smurts either by helping other individuals, or when you kill enemies. 

For me the game shines in the puzzles. However, you’ll be fighting interesting bosses and some are not that easy to eliminate. Oh, by the way, you’ll be armed with a GumGumGun which shoots coloured gums. There is a place where you can upgrade your weapons at a specific store in Popocity.

Splendid artwork and the soundtrack is very cute. For the controls, whether you use the mouse and keyboard or the gamepad, they work fine and it is very easy to allocate binding keys to your inventory.

Positives:
~~~~~~~ 

-	Splendid artwork
-	Well-designed world
-	Great puzzles
-	Fun fighting bosses
-	Fun dialogues
-	Achievements and trading cards

Negatives:
~~~~~~~~    

-	 I think the fighting bosses could be a notch harder

This game is a gem - thoroughly entertaining and fun to play!

8/10

Key provided by developer/publisher for review purposes. Any opinions expressed are entirely my own!

32273213.review:
This game is just adorable. I honestly can't think of anything bad to say about this game. It's very reasonable in length for its price and doesn't outstay its welcome by throwing at you boss after boss, and you discovering new environments and new sights to see at a very constant rate. 

PROS:
+Excellent, ADORABLE art style. 
+SPECTACULAR environments for multiple hub areas that were a delight to explore
+Legit, GOOD bosses that were fun to fight even with the simple controls
+Wide variety of fun items to use and try out. Even if some didn't serve a purpose, they were still SO CUTE. SO MANY HATS!!
+The collectible filmstrips that are hidden throughout the game are a DELIGHT to watch! Collecting all of them, even using a guide, is a must!
+High amount of polish in the game's interaction with characters and items. You can bring a character or item to a character who mentioned the former, and you will almost always get a delightful, distinct conversation.
+Interesting lore included in the game regarding the various races you meet and play as.

I hesitate to call the below flaws because they are mostly nitpicks and doesn't bring a detriment to the game. I enjoyed my experience regardless.

Areas of Improvement:
-Respawning enemies. Every new area that you get to (the next screen) will spawn a set number of enemies every time. You can never clear these out and they get irritating after you kill them the Nth time around.
-There is a part of the game where you have to navigate a huge puzzle room to pass through. This segment was a grind and I spent way too long figuring it out. Coupled with the above complaint, this segment takes points away from an otherwise perfect game. You are definitely rewarded upon completion though.
-Near the end, a certain character will give an expository lore dump about the world and how to defeat a certain final boss. This was extremely dry and confusing. I appreciate the dev's efforts to flesh out the world, but this could have been done better.

All in all this was one of the most interesting and enjoyable single player games I've played in a while. If you aren't fazed by the nitpicks, this is a must-buy if the trailer in any way appeals to you. Good job dev, and I look forward to future games!

32232896.review:
"You know a game's good when it's been almost a year since it's been released and it still has a 100% review rating."

That was pretty much what I said to myself when I just randomly found this game on my discovery queue. It just caught my interest and I thought it'd be a fun explorative endeavor to try this game out. But oh boy howdy, I totally didn't expect what was coming next. To sum it up, I guess I found out why the game has a 100% rating.

Everything in this game is just so captivating and weird, it makes you want to explore more and more and learn all about it. The world of Wuppo is colorful and happy, perfectly crafted to keep a smile in your face for the entire duration of the ride. It reminds me of the times I first played videogames, seeing big worlds and exploring everything they had to offer with a deep child-like interest. I didn't think that any games of this generation would be capable of recreating this sensation, but I can safely say that Wuppo does that with utmost grace.

But enough with vague statements, let's go straight to the precise details about the game:

Gameplay-wise, it's a metroidvania/shoot-em-up/adventure mash-up. It has a big emphasis on exploration and interaction. The game doesn't have much combat in it, which would make it rather easy... That is, until you meet the bosses. They might be a bit tough at first, but all are a fair challenge. Most of the actual challenge of the game is in solving puzzles, going through some simple obstacles and fighting bosses. But while you're not actually doing any of that, you'll be mostly looking for interactions or items to collect. The game doesn't really guide you much, so exploring all you can is the best method of progressing.

In terms of aesthetics, it is extremely colorful and happy, and pretty much everything is criminally adorable. But even with the seemingly simplistic looks, the world feels filled to the brim with life all around. Wherever you go, you will find other creatures just minding their business, moving back and forth while sometimes carrying something. All the movement makes the world feel incredibly lively and believable.

Now about the story... It starts quite small, with you just simply trying to find a new home, but it then somehow manages to go all around. The complexity of the story grows surprisingly fast. There is plenty of lore and backstory to uncover, all only limited to how much of the game you explore. Also, you better keep track of all the new words you'll be learning from the game, there's gonna be quite a lot of them.

And about the content. As of writing this, I got 17 hours of play time for the game. And 17 hours is exactly what I needed to finish it with a meticulous search for collectibles. But after reading through the guides, there seems to still be a bunch I've missed. There is plenty of stuff to uncover like new items, more maximum health by doing things that make you happy (yes, you gain more health by merely searching for happiness), the collectible filmstrips to reveal more lore, and the boss fights that are sometimes rather well hidden. And even after finishing the game, you can still try and show off your skills on the boss rush mode you'll unlock then. Exploring the world is extremely rewarding, giving you quite a bunch of surprises.

Overall, I REALLY liked this game, and I am absolutely certain that you will like it too. There is pretty much nothing to hate on it.

31934150.review:
violence is on the rampage, People have become cynical and apathetic with life. Pain and suffering has no bounds and even video games are not afraid to show these issues. 

Lovingly rendered blood and body parts fly apart realisticly more and more every generations, and always remind us that its your fault that you caused this. We either become heros in the darkest of times, shattered from what we see, or become the monsters of no boundries to continue the cycle of killing.

and then theres Wuppo

First thing i want to say that i really like this game, even though im the sort of person that laughs at dead baby jokes, watches robot chicken, and shockingly of all, enjoy's POSTAL 2 Like 99% of the world population, if they were raised like me. 

So what we have here is a game made by two people and i don't know if their a couple or not, and ironicly their names sound as jibberish as the words you'll hear in the game.  Who comes up with the word splennaker, if i spelled it right. So it throws at you a nonsense dictionary, for a world of nonsense. So after beating the game you'll know more words from this game, then any of the unusual words from a spelling bee.

[u]Gameplay[/u]

Now how do i say this.... its a very unusual metroidvania. How the game works is that it pulls a shadow of the collosus on you, or LISA if your a masochist who thinks suffering is fun, by making alot of boss encounters put to their fullest. Each boss encounter is unique and has the flaws of what happens when you add to much boss varerity. What it means is that the mid-way bosses will be harder then the end game boss. That giant ball of lint has killed me more times then the world ending uhh... attempt at drawing a human face. 

The only way to kill these bosses, (YES i said kill in a game that has the Nintendo kid friendly vibe to it) is to use a varerity of weapons like.... some sort of tube that shoots paint, and a  'bucket' that makes you spit water. This review is gona have more full stops then the prince of persia: sands of time script. They are all ranged and you are always encouraged to use the full mobility of the, Wum? did i say that right and when you defeat enemies, sometimes the drop smurt OK HOW IS THIS DUTCH!?! So you must be confused with all this nonsense as i am, well if you really want to know what the story is, that you are guy finding home, ok end of plot. 

So in between the slightly engaging boss fights it has one of the best use of pacing i have ever seen in a game. What it does is that it makes you uncertian of what will happen next. One time i was talking to an elevator operator to my own whim, and then i see a bunch of chefs run down the hall. I stoped the dialouge and went to see what is going on, then boss fight. If it was most games it would wrestle the controls from you for a cutscene or make you go down an obvious corridor to continue the story, but events naturally unfold in the game. So it feels like something that is worth the time and effort to be involved in, instead of a fancy script sequence with explosions and, oh look the sky looks slightly more realistic.

[u]atmosphere[/u]

Everything about this game has this cuetsy artstyle of a saturday morning cartoon without the bad script writing. It has the perfect blend of crudness and attention to detail to make a massive world. After all were stuck with a cotton ball for legs and have the defensive capability for ourselves as a cotton ball. So its designed to make everything look big and cluttered with special affects.The game can manage under a hundred ai walking simutaniously, and enough bullets going around the screen to embarase a Bethesda RPG. Impressive for something made in a free game maker engine.

So why does it have this, well to make this strange world of nonsense. Everything is made as it needs to, and makes alot of strange locations that are worth checking out. Especially having to wait real time in a line, A LINE, what other game makes you wait in a line and i spent over 10 minutes waiting for the worst rollercoaster ride, not even worthy for an addition to LEGO land. But i went on, because it felt believable and everyone in the game isn't another dull npc that does their predictable routes.... like a bethesda RPG, ok i'll stop.

[u]conclusion[/u]
Wuppo not even that name links to anything in the game, is a fantastic metroidvania game with satisfying uh, paint gun play. Full of charm, hardwork, and creativity to make something 'Magicaaaaaaaaaaal', ok its a good game, no more sarcasim. It has the friendly 'anyone can play it' vibe without feeling forced and artificial. 

Its a game thats you will end up playing once through two days, which is enough. Whats made is made perfectly without overstaying or underwhelming and the best part is, no sequel bait. So the two Men, Women, couple i dunno im not dutch, will make another game and i will look foward to their latest installment.

So in short BUY THIS GAME.
[spoiler]unless your busy i dunno i have to much free time, everyone keeps telling me to get a job, but thats ok because its a free country and no ones stopping you from leaving and dying from the cold... am i gonna die. [/spoiler]

29973072.review:
Wuppo is probably the most fun I've had playing an adventure game for a while. The graphics are simplistic, but it fits very well with the game's play style. It's a charming game with bullet hell- like battles, and the bosses are creative. The music also fits each boss, and there are plenty of collectibles to try to get to extend the game past the basic story. There are upgrades, and the boss rush is also something good to try out. I would highly recommend Wuppo if you'd like adventure games, or just want a new game to play. The game is small and it could use the support, so give it a chance if you could.

Would give Wuppo an 8/10, as it does lack in length, and things aren't always well explained.

29626138.review:
Wuppo is a hard game to pin down in a review, but I'll try to be descriptive and add some practical details to help make up the minds of anyone that tries to decide if this game is right for them. 

First off, what immediately will catch your eye, is that the game looks very "cute". This cuteness is not is not just added for its own sake, but its aesthetic and style really serves the purpose to complement and add to the feel of the world. What I mean by this, is that the world is very friendly and open to exploration and has generally a very laid back atmosphere. Most of the world's inhabitants that you encounter are friendly and can be interacted with for some possible rewards or information. Some can be triggered into attacking you, but if this happens when you have the bird equipped for example, I can't really blame them.

At the start of the adventure you are kicked out of the room you live in and become forced to explore the world and find a new place to live. You traverse the world through platforming and this doesn't mean going from left to right; you are free to choose where to go, but you'll quickly find obstacles that you have to overcome in order to reach the newer parts of the map. The platforming itself is very satisfying with good reactive controls and almost no frustration due to there being almost no enemies or hazardous pitfalls. Should you die, or miss a jump and fall all the way down, there are plenty of potential save points that you can quick load to. This may sound that this makes the game too easy, but I feel this was just done to not hinder you in exploring the world. The real challenge lies in the bosses and "puzzles".

Should you encounter an enemy, then you can take fire at them with the weapon you have equipped -- this will mostly only be necessary for the boss encounters.

The controls itself were straightforward enough, but they did require me to get used to them. I use a controller and when you fire your weapon you control where the attack goes with the right analog stick (360 degrees). I normally use the "A" button -- XBOX controller -- for jumping, but this makes attacking while jumping hard to pull off. The game therefore starts with the jump button being assigned to the left bumper (LB), but after some experimenting I decided to switch this to the right bumper (RB) instead. The game lets you re-assign any button you want. It does seem that because of the way you control your attack, this is a platformer that is easy to be played with a mouse and keyboard.

Most of the weapons you use will fire an continues stream of particles at the location you are pointing to. This means that the bosses have plenty of hit points and you usually have to hit them a lot of times to whittle them down. The bosses can be quite challenging, but they often are also a highlight of the game. I can think of 7/8 off the top of my head that had some really creative and memorable designs in both their looks as well as in their way of fighting -- usually with multiple stages -- that can easily match up with the ones from various classic 2D platformers in terms of the quality of gameplay. They didn't add the boss run as a feature for nothing.

To make the boss encounters easier, you can up your health from 100 to a maximum of 200. You can get these bonus "feel good" health points in a variety of ways, like simply just talking to certain NPC's, or participating in events. I once got a point by just passing a painting I had made that had been hung up in the hall. The most straightforward way is to find and collect the various "filmstrips" hidden throughout the world. When watching them some of these will give you a point, but by collecting all of them in an area, this automatically gives you 5 life points. It doesn't sound like much, but the bosses can hit hard and most boss encounters have parts where you can get back lost health. So, any way to survive an onslaught, raises your chance to be victorious.

One part of the game that can be off-putting to some, is that it features situations where you have to come up with a solution in order to proceed further into the game -- it has adventure game elements after all. I'm hesitant to use the word "puzzles" even if it is what it boils down to, because this can be associated with the minigame-like scenarios you can find in point and click adventure games; Wuppo is more action oriented. Most of the time you are required to search for certain items, which you then use to open a new path. Talking to the NPC's can give you info to what items you need and what use they have. Also, equipping certain items can trigger events. Personally I would say that I encountered only a couple of situations where I was stumped for a bit, but I can understand that some people don't like this element. However, there are some good guides available now, so you can look up a solution for if you get stuck.

What I consider to be the best part of Wuppo is its fantastic world and the amount of world-building that goes on in it. A lot of  people are raving about the "charm" of this game and indeed, it oozes it. This is of course highly subjective on my part, but my experience with Wuppo, I can best describe as Nintendo-esque. Honestly, while playing Wuppo, I immediately started comparing it to the Zelda and Paper Mario games. Of course, Wuppo is not as polished as what Nintendo produces, but we can't hold an indie game to those standards. Anyway, the background of the world; all the interactions with its characters; the situations you find yourself in; and how the characters behave in all of the different areas in relation to each other, it all fits and comes together wonderfully. You really get the felling that you are walking around in a fleshed out world where all of the characters have their own lives and way of thinking. As an example, in one part of the game you have to use a train, this train has an in-game schedule, so it can be that you have to wait in line during which time you get to observe Wums going all over the place. Then, when the train arrives, you have to wait a bit for the departing passengers and after that the cleaning crew. The wait isn't very long -- less than a minute --  but these little details add so much to the world and they can be found everywhere; clearly a lot of love went into this game.

The soundtrack fits the game perfectly and adds so much to its charm. Looking back, there really are quite a lot of terrific tunes that build up the atmosphere.

All in all, it's hard to give Wuppo an objective numerical rating. I could say it deserves an 8 out of 10, because it does have some rough edges, but when the game works, I felt like playing a 10 out of 10 game. It has such a uniquely genuine feel to it, which is too abstract to really factor into the sum of its parts; the people that are attuned to its vibe, will enjoy it immensely for this reason alone, but this will not necessarily apply to everyone. Neverthelessl, the world-building; the interactions with the varied colorful charactars; the boss encounters (most of them); the art style; the terrific soundtrack; the sense of humor and whimsical nature; the fun platforming; and the writing of the story and various dialogues, all contribute to an amazing game, that will put a smile on almost anyone's face and deserves to be labeled as a "gem".

Wow, this review went on longer than I thought it would, but I had some free time on my hands. For people who don't like ramblings like this, just skip it.

29282223.review: A really creative and quirky adventure-platformer, defintely one of the most underrated indie releases of 2016. Imagine Yoshi's Island meets an adventure game.

29235692.review:
Got this as a Christmas pressie (tyty!)

It is an indie game and as such it lacks the polished precision that should be expected from larger productions (and we did have some occasional freezing issues, nothing game breaking).

Now that's out of the way though!

..it was awesome.

It has an explorable living breathing world filled with other inhabitants - you are certainly just part of the crowd at many times.
It is utterly charming and at times very funny.
Controls were mostly very nicely done.
It's one of those games where even once you've finished it you don't really want to leave, and happily the game lets you continue to amble around finding new little interactions and secrets even after the story is over (and there are loooads of random little things to find, mostly just for fun).
It has achievements, but doesn't hand them out for every little thing - you want em you're gonna have to work for them! (In fact I believe you could actually complete the game and only earn 3 of them).
Devs are hugely responsive, fixing bugs as they are found and helping solve user problems (even user caused user problems).
Platforming difficult is fairly easy making the game a mix of story, exploration and boss fights.

After I had been playing this for a while my bf started asking me what I was playing. Normally I have to drag him kicking and screaming towards anything I want him to play. This he had installed and was waiting to play almost immediately.

Thus followed a ridiculous back and forth. I mean I probably would have stopped after finishing the game on normal, but he decided to try insane and of course then I had to as well...

I totally suck at the bosses. Well I have persistance on my side which is how I eventually got through insane,  but I suspect a complete Boss Run (which requires some actual skill) will forever be beyond my grasp. The bosses are nicely put together and there are some fun mechanics to play with as well as various weapon upgrades and other useful items that offer you choices in strategy as you come up against them.

Totally worth getting. :)

Simply the best game of 2016.

The trailer of the game only shows you how beautiful it is, but what makes this game unique you'll only understand if you play it.

But to put it simply: It's in the details. To go to Popocity (one of the areas in the game) you have to wait for the train to arrive. The train sometimes is late just like in real life. And there are escalators. Real escalators that work. 
There's an amusement park, but to ride the attractions you need to wait in line, again just like real life.

There's such attention to details that is only possible when a game is made with love and passion.

Charming, entertaining and full of delightful details all around. I found myself enjoying every second of the experience, as soon as I started playing it. To my surprise, as I'm not even a big fan of the adventure-platformer genre, and I had primarily picked the game to give a try to my new Xbox One controller (on which it plays wonderfully, btw-- and options for other types of controllers are also included, shows so much legit care for the playability, something often unseen on big-budget games). By the amount of brilliant little ideas spread over the world of Wuppo, you can easily tell how much love was invested on the making of it.

Only wish I had found about this game sooner, honestly, as it's one of those rare few that make me feel BETTER about my day after playing it. Definitely deserves more attention here on Steam, imo.

10/10 - Wuppo will put many a smile on your face.

心目中的神作。因为谜之声做的直播而入的坑，怎么会有这么可爱的游戏。
一开始我还以为这只是一个很小的游戏，没想到到后面展开那么多，很显然制作组有很大的野心，对城市化、种族矛盾、生命起源都有自己的独特见解。
蜡笔画风，简约又不失个性。
wum各有各的个性，主角更是搞怪的无厘头，表情非常丰富。
人物都很暖心，有的支线让我非常感动。

+可爱的画风
+有趣的故事
+庞大的世界观
+细腻的操作手感
+幽默的对白

-反人类的成就

如果你喜欢可爱的画风，不要错过这一款游戏。

Throw together Yoshi's Island, River City Ransom, and the "tough bosses" philosophy that pervades modern gaming, and you have Wuppo.

26806280.review:
Wuppo is a side scroller shooter with some tiny elements of metroidvania and platforming thrown in there for good measure, the art style isn't the most high fidelity but I think it's really charming on it's own right, sorta like a cartoon or one of those short animations from the 2000s, I'm not sure if everybody digs it but I find it really nice and kinda cute personally and the game has a really good soundtrack too that fits in very well with this aesthetic and can also really surprise you at how flexible it can be in terms of the mood or tone it can set for a given area or scene, but I don't wanna get too deep into that because it's spoilers territory

The core gameplay consists of exploration, talking to all sorts of NPCs and fighting things with your paint gun or Gumgumgun as the game calls it, although you also get extra weapons and can upgrade a few as the game progresses. The game's technically structured into levels or I guess the more fitting description would be regions, as you keep unlocking the next one as you progress but the world is still open and explorable if you want to backtrack for instance, and you even do unlock fast travel very very late game, each area will have a different objective to progress to the following one which will usually be about solving a puzzle, obtaining a certain item or fighting a boss of which there are 17 of them

I think most of the bosses are generally well designed and fun to fight against but they do get a little bit bad near the end of the game, where you'll fight what feels like just a bunch of regular enemies, but they're considered a boss for some reason as if it was inflating the total boss count and I don't want to spoil too much here but I don't really like the final boss all that much either, sure it's hard but I think that fight is more of a clusterfuck of projectiles than anything else, also your weapons aren't really all that great at shooting directly upwards but that guy tends to float around anyways often times just barely out of range for your weapons, but then there's the Giant Dust Monster or the Rock Statue which are some of my favorites which were challenging but also really enjoyable to fight, they all have their own unique patterns which you have to learn to tackle them efficiently, sure you may die a few times finding out those patterns, but that's part of the fun of fighting these bosses to me, difficulty varies between normal, hard and insane, which changes how much damage enemies do to you, I personally went with hard for a decent challenge but nothing too far out there

The puzzles on the other hand even if there are few of them, they are all well put together in my opinion, they're not overly complex or anything but they play on the game's lore quite nicely, there's a big temple near the end and I think that's the best example of it in the game, it really is something quite good and there are definetly some crazy surprises there, part of which is some of what I mentioned about the sountrack too but I really don't want to ruin it for you

Also about the objectives I mentioned earlier they're usually good too but there is one big exception around the mid game where you go to this city and it has this "credit" system, where you can contribute to increase an overall score of sorts of the town and you can do it through a couple different minigames which are fun don't get me wrong here, but the overall score that you need seems to be way more than it should've because you have to repeat these minigames a looot to get there, to the point where it gets really repetitive and almost feels like it was done to pad out the game a little bit, I'm not a fan of waiting mechanics in general but I do think they have their time and place, like in the Splenkhakker park for instance where you have to wait around for the rides and stuff, I mean it's just a fun optional thing and I think it adds some charm to the region overall

And that's one thing I think that this game's honestly full of, charm, I mean Splenkhakker park? The names of these races are kinda wacky, I don't know if it means anything, I mean the developers are Norwegean so there is a language barrier there I suppose, but there's also the humour in the dialogue and it's all upbeat and lighthearted, it's definetly a really nice experience when you meet a new character and get to talk to them which will usually make you smile just reading what they have to say, the story is rather simple in the grand scheme of things, but it's things like these that carry the game and elevate it to something really unique and special and that ties in to the collectables that this game has which are Filmstrips which show you a little bit more about this game's world and lore, or just some funny situations and then there's Happyness, which you can get by doing all sorts of stuff around the levels or on conversations with NPCs where you choose a specific dialogue option or do something for them, not your typical quests or anything by the way, the game's more clever than that, there are also a few fun secrets and easter eggs out there so I'd definetly recommend you keep your eyes peeled while exploring and also return to some older areas once you're late into the game

So overall this game's gonna take you around 12 to 15 hours to beat depending on how much you want to explore and all that, but personally I really think this game's worth it, it's a really nice fun experience that doesn't really take itself all that seriously and I think we need more platformers like this, it kinda reminds me of Hell Yeah! Wrath of the Dead Rabbit, which was a similar game in spirit in my eyes, like the way I felt playing it, it's hard to explain and I'm probably sounding kinda pretentious here so I'll just say this, I'd definetly recommend Wuppo for pretty much almost anybody and it's gonna make you really happy while playing it and for just $15 dollars or your regional equivalent I think it's a nice purchase

虽说这是调侃，但是无论是天气还是时间设定，都给人一种意外萌的感觉

话说这个游戏BOSS战的设计，在场景拉远整体缩小的情况下，我觉得我不大能看出自己在哪 。。感觉是用第六感在移动

有几个想说的点：
1. filmstrip总觉得找齐有点难，花了很多时间摸各个角落还是漏了几个；
2. 几个需要触发的场景很有意思，比如游乐园的stoplight （BOSS战）和tunnel里的ghost (赠送upgrade material和一点点钱 ..)
3. 值得注意的是，bucket在你买了4个artifact之后还可以升级，地点在游乐场左边的island

    不推荐送报纸！！！not old town again ！！
5. Fried kneft不能直接买到，你可以选择用破钩子钓kneft，或者直接购买kneft；然后送到popocity的snackstop，这样就可以买到了。顺便一提，把这个送给工厂老板，他会给你开一个工厂到中心的快捷通道。

26340796.review:
[h1]The charm of this game is simply [i]unreasonable[/i]![/h1]

The two-man dev team that created Wuppo has "globbed" together a living, breathing world for the player to explore! I thoroughly enjoyed nearly every minute of the game that I played, and will certainly revisit it in the future. The storyline and dialogue can be a bit abstract at times, but I found the humor in the game spot on, and amidst much laughter I came down with several lingering cases of permagrin! Certain cutscenes along the storyline are very visually intense, and I found myself very immersed in what was occurring. The ending of the game becomes a bit... confusing (as the lore gets dramatically expanded and [spoiler] you're given "fast travel" access throughout the world, to tie up loose ends or keep exploring [/spoiler]), but I felt very satisfied after beating the game and pleased with my accomplishment.
Some of the bosses are quite challenging, and the inventive/creative design of the world and its inhabitants always kept me smiling and impressed. The music was also quite catchy! At some point I will certainly buy the soundtrack, as I'm finding certain songs stuck in my head throughout my recent days. Wuppo's music will continue to play in my head as serve as a mnemonic draw to the unadulterated fun I had while playing this game.

Overall, I sincerely enjoyed my time with Wuppo, and believe it deserves a lot more recognition that it currently has. I wholeheartedly recommend it! Thank you, Knuist & Perzik, for creating such a pleasant world to explore!

26138243.review:
EDIT: Wuppo has been patched quite a lot since my review, so some of my critique may have been addressed by now. I may replay the game and update my review in the near future.

CAUTIOUS RECOMMENDATION
In short, the game is fun but falls short and kind of disappointing.

I am impressed with Wuppo. The world building is fantastic and the developers went at length to make the world as organic as possible. Exploration and problem solving are enjoyable despite being frustrating at times. Some of the bosses are very fun, too, and the soundtrack is memorable and a joy to listen to. Wuppo is also very charming, with many funny moments and easter eggs.

But there are many problems with the game that keep it from its full potential. Some boss designs are questionable and started to drop the ball close to the end of the game, there is an entire portion of the game that is a literal grind and has very questionable navigation structure, the game forces you to wait at times (the developer has stated this was intentional because he found waiting to be half the fun at amusement parks, meanwhile my family always tries to get fast passes in order to skip lines), and some mechanics felt entirely pointless and added tedium (there is a tiny area in the game that you spend only a few minutes in but for some reason it has its own currency). Also the game is very short and you are at the end of the game before you know it.

After I killed the final boss, I recollected my experience through the game only to realize that I didn't do much at all. It feels like that the game does not have much content in the end because a large portion of the game is padding. The game took 7 years, but Wuppo does not feel like a 7 year effort.

So with these in mind, I give Wuppo a cautious recommendation. You will enjoy exploring the game world and its secrets, solving problems to progress, but be mindful that it will make you do tedious things and the game does not last very long. Also you will sometimes get stuck.

这是一个仅通关普通难度下的玩家撰写的评论。
正在尝试通关I难度。

总体来说，这是一部好游戏。属于横版探索类游戏，类似恶魔城系列。
需要用鼠标和键盘协调操作。

音乐与实在是足够可~爱的画风让游戏的体验感非常好(｀・ω・´)
世界观相对完整，从故事的角度上来说，也算一步一步解释了Wuppo世界的发展与每个人物的特点。
通过收集影片的方式来作为收集要点，能体验到不同的人物的性格与情感。

比如如果不看Carlo的日记影片，恐怕不会知道其实Carlo是多么关爱那个ice cream wum（笑）。
而且还有其他各种各样的小彩蛋和小游戏可以去收集。

对抗BOSS的战斗方式多种多样……需要不断的摸索打法。尤其在国内没有攻略和解说视频的情况下，这可是一块未开垦的良田啊（被迫(-_-#)。

如果概括故事的话_(:3」∠)_大概是一个肥宅被赶出酒店后然后偷渡到城市顺手拯救城市后又在敌后阵地考古最后拯救世界的故事吧(￣ε(#￣) Σ

好了，说一些缺点啊。

1.游戏中当故事剧情将要触发还未触发的时候，不要随意移动或者与他人对话，这可能会引起卡屏BUG。
2.故事有点大团圆，结局很美好且单一，虽然很符合画风……但和神作的距离还差一些要素。如果要是能有多结局的话也许会让游戏更丰富…？
3.当前没有中文版……这将非常限制中国人的体验（￣へ￣）不过英文版的更原汁原味一点吧，不知道未来有没有计划考虑中文版。
4.这个游戏有自己的时间系统……也就是很多事情要算着时间来。每个商店还都有自己的存留现金，卖太多东西商店会最后付不起（其实这条并不是缺点，但确实稍微有点浪费时间）。

以上就是关于Wuppo这部游戏的全部评论，推荐玩。

25939540.review:
Wuppo is a cute and charming game that goes against using conventional means of guiding the player, and instead requires you to be observant and to pay attention to what the enviorment and its inhabitants tell you. This causes the game to feel much more rewarding when you figure out how to advance. There are also optional collectibles in the game in the form of film strips. Even though they are optional, I highly recommend that you find as many as you can, as they reveal information about various characters and places in the game, and some of that information can be very helpful.

The platforming is solid, it has tight controls and proper physics on rounded bouncy platforms such as mushrooms. The combat is also good, although simplistic, with unique and challenging bosses that appear in the most unexpected places. The only real criticism I have with Wuppo is that if you're somewhat of a completionist like me, aquiring everything is a massive undertaking, specifically when it comes to buying all the unique items from all the shops. Grinding out all of the smurt (the in-game currency) takes a very long time, and the process becomes very tedious very quickly.

All in all, I highly recommend this game to anyone with an interest in adorable creatures, and games that reward thoughtful observation as well as good platforming skills.

A simple little project by two individuals began seven years ago, one that I've followed from the beginning. From a mere unfinished alpha demo to a complete and playable game, I've seen it all.

Wuppo feels so... Alive. You really feel like you're a part of a living, breathing planet! It does a masterful job of balancing the fun dialogue and fast-paced gameplay with a massively diverse slew of ambiance and atmospheric music tracks.

Should you have any technical problems, such as the game running slowly or a controller issue, they're not difficult to iron out! All you have to do is tweak your options once, and the rest of the game is yours to enjoy.

I highly recommend it!

The dialogue was hilarious, and i found the jokes to be very amusing. The artwork and animation for this game was very well done, and very cute. The gameplay was absolutely enjoyable and fun. 25906184.review:
Welcome to the strange world of Wuppo. A world filled with Wums, Blussers, Splenkhakkers, Fnakkers and a handful of other races. You are a Wum living in the Wumhouse, a house where every Wum can live in leisure, but seeing more and more Wums leaving to the new underground city of technical development Popocity. After you've made a mess of the hallways in the Wumhouse, AGAIN, you've been thrown out of the house. Now homeless, your adventure begins where you meet other characters, fight strange bosses, solve enviromental puzzles, help communities, save the world, and find a new home.

Strong Points:

+ The world - Building a world ain't easy, especially one with races and technologies so different from ours. But the developer managed to not only create a consistent world, but one that feels very alive and full of things to explore. A great achievement.

+ NPCs and their interactions - The world is filled with small little creatures with small little lives. They don't feel like static objects that speak the same sentence their whole lives, but as real and alive creatures. Big plus for writing and coding all these dialogues for all the little interactions, even when they are insignificant to the plot, just to keep the immersion.

+ Music - The soundtrack is gorgeous and fits to every situation our little Wum is thrown into. A great achievement by the composer.

+ Animations - Very fluid. Love how the expression of our little Wum changes at different dialogue options.

+ Difficulty - The bosses and environmental puzzles are sometimes hard and challenging, but never unfair. Great job.

Average Points:

T Gameplay - You don't play Wuppo for it's inventive gameplay: it's your average Indie Metroidvania. But that isn't needed for a game like Wuppo, the gameplay is the medium you use to explore and interact with the world, and it does that just fine.

Weak Points:

- Art style - Sorry Lars, but most of it looks like it was made in MSPaint. Sometimes it looks nice, and sometimes it's just plain ugly. However, the art style is consistent throughout the game, so it doesn't break the immersion.

Conclusion:

Wuppo is a charming game with a great world to explore that feels very alive. Recommended!

25899764.review:
Wuppo is an incredible game to be brought to us by just two people. WITH THE EXCEPTION OF ONE MAJOR ISSUE.

I think about games that hit the closest to real, honest classic gaming. Authentic and not forced or fabricated. For example, I think Bleed is the closest an indie game has gotten to a legitimate Gunstar Heroes successor. With Wuppo, I think this is the first indie game I've played to feel, in its presentation, with its cast of quirky characters, with its music, its gameplay systems, etc. like a Nintendo-made game. It may not LOOK like one (The art is more like a very cute spin on An Untitled Story), but it sounds, acts and feels like one in just about every way. If you don't like the direction the Paper Mario series has gone, this game is not Paper Mario, but it has that same kind of writing, and worldbuilding, and overall fun and adorability.

There is a huge amount of bosses (17!!), a theme park with rides you can ride on, an underground city with jobs (we'll get to that), an apartment complex full of nutty people, a forest tribe of flower people, islands in the sea to find, another dimension entirely-- the world of Wuppo is enormous. Not quite the size of a game like Opoona (another similarly quirky and wonderful game), but much larger than you'd expect on first playing the game.

The combat and general interface are relatively simple. Point and click to fire, WASD to move. You can throw items on pedestals and give items and money to people for trade. Part of the fun of the game is finding things in shops that you have no idea what they are, and sometimes you might need them. Why does a city sell a diving helmet? Why does an apartment sell rocks? You'll find out!

Okay, let's talk about the elephant in the room, and I haven't read reviews lately so I dunno how people will feel about this, but: THE POPOCITY SECTION OF THE GAME IS REALLY TEDIOUS. You will spend about 3 hours in Popocity, an underground city underneath the Wum village, trying to build Credit for the city in order to finance the city's big expansion. This means getting jobs, performing tasks, buying items from shops, staying in the hotel, etc. 

This is all fine, and I liked the concept INITIALLY. The problem is that there just isn't enough to do here. You can sell newspapers (and after doing it 8 times you unlock a side quest, which-- by the way, that tells you something about the tedium doesn't it? Doing the same minigame 8 times?) but the only change is how many papers you deliver, and whether it's to Central or to Old Town. You can participate in debates at City Hall once a day, but there are very few topics (we already decided on the painted smakoffel!! Three times!!) . You can find Kneft monsters for Credit once a day, which only varies slightly in how the enemy waves spawn. You can buy items from a seedy shop at outrageous prices for 1000 credits a pop. And you can work in the factory, which consists of jumping up and down on a seesaw over and over again.

There's just not enough to any of these jobs to make grinding out the credit fun. Each time you do several jobs and go back to the Credit final tally you'll be left with a feeling of "really?? I still have that much to go??". I feel like this can be fixed either by increasing the credit that jobs give or by providing more variety to the jobs. For example, why not more topics at City Hall? Why not a police job tracking down criminals in the city? What if a machine breaks down at the factory and you can get extra Credit for fixing it? If the message is "work is supposed to be tedious", then it comes across the same as the infamous treadmill from Super Paper Mario -- in the end, it's still tedious and that's all that matters.

ALL THAT SAID, Wuppo is a fabulous game. I can't not speak about that section because it makes up a third of the game, but the other two thirds are so weird, so wild, so wonderful, so witty, so silly, that it kept me smiling all the way to the end. It's one of my top 3 indie games of the year, to go along with Copy Kitty and Rive as the best experiences I've had on Steam in 2016.

25880939.review:
I've only cracked the surface of Wuppo and I'm loving it.  The controls and animations are fluid and feel natural, and there's so much to discover and learn in the early game that I have to give it a quick review for those curious.  Wuppo has the same charm that I would expect from an entry in Yoshi's series of games or better yet, Kirby.  The world is immediately presented to you as being well-established and it makes no apologies for bringing you, the player, in before you have any clue as to what it's all about.  Tutorial nonsense is kept at an absolute minimum, with only the most obtuse details being presented in easy to digest comments from NPCs.  The music is brilliant and adds a level of depth you'd think was only reserved for games in much different calibers; the soundtrack is refreshing and simply breathtaking, with some elements being pseudo-rhythm based.  The first couple boss (I think?) encounters were super hard but gave off that lightbulb moment when I realized the pattern and how the arena had to lend itself to my advantage.  

An open world that doesn't hold your hand but also doesn't try to diminish your abilities at every turn- why can't more games understand this simple concept?  Yes, there is a gap between Nintendo Hard and Tryhard Hard.

Wuppo is not a game that panders to anything, really.  It is brave, and dares to be it's own entity without selling itself out to tired gimmicks or lazy tropes.  It even forces on you its own, wildly different [I]control scheme[/I] and at first I was searching for ways to rebind my controller but after 20 minutes or so I realized that this beautiful game was asking me to try something new, and that, right there, is when I realized the scope of Wuppo's depth.

Finally a game for Nintendo platformer lovers, one that wraps you up in the brilliance of its design instead of substituting creativity with cheap, artificial difficulty.  I had no idea what it was when I bought it, and I still really don't understand even a small percentage of what this game actually [I]is[/I], but man, I'm glad I gave it a chance!

25853731.review: This is a pretty interesting adventure game.  It sort of reminds me of "An Untitled Story" meets a point and click adventure game.  It has that hand-crafted art style from Untitled Story, but it also has a fleshed out world full of interesting characters that just oozes with charm.  It's not a very combat heavy game, so don't expect to be running through rooms full of baddies while exploring the world.  Most screens don't have anything to fight you, but there are pretty serious boss fights that will test you.  I played on Hard mode and I found the bosses to be a healthy challenge, never really unfair once you understand how they work.  Overall the game took me around 10 hours, and there is a ton to see and do in the world.   There's a lot of stuff I didn't find, so you could get even more out of it if you are a completionist.

25810851.review:
I've known absolutely nothing about this game until a few days ago when my friend--who had been following the game's development--told me to check it out.  I had nothing but her word to go off of, and boy am I glad I gave this game a shot.  Going in, the first thing you'll notice is that this game is hilariously cute.  But the deeper you fall down the rabbit hole, the more you realize how much this game has to offer. It has a lot of charm and a lot of heart, especially seeing how it mostly comes from only two indie developers, and the soundtrack is very engrossing (I'd recommend getting the ultimate edition if you've got the money for it).  The puzzles can be very tricky at times, but they're never too overwhelming--especially since you have an in-game guide that can toss you hints if you're stuck.

The game has quite a few bugs here and there, but there are save spots all over the place and it literally takes a second to save, so as long you don't forget to pop into one, you should never lose more than a couple minutes' progress from a crash.  The devs have been VERY involved with taking feedback from players and are actively seeking out bugs to fix for their next update, and it just goes to show how much they care about the game and their fans.

All in all the game will take up about 13 hours on your first playthrough, many more if you're a completionist or want to give one of the higher difficulties a shot.  Between the cute characters, beautiful scenery, enchanting soundtrack, and fascinating story, I'd say this is definitely worth a buy.

상점페이지를 염탐(?)하다가 우연히 이 게임을 보게되었고, 데모로 잠깐 했다가 꽂혀서 얼티밋 에디션 꾸러미를 사버렸다.
바이바이, 내 통장잔고!

일단... 귀엽다.  발발거리는 4족보행 찹쌀떡을 보니까 귀여워 죽을뻔했다. 우클릭 하면 휘파람도 분다. 삑삑.
이 귀여운 찹쌀떡(?)들을 Wum이라고 하는데, 플레이 영상을 보니까 '웜'이라 읽는 듯 하다.

진행해보면 그냥 스토리 따라 모험하고, 보스 때려잡고, 맵 곳곳에 숨겨져 있는 필름을 찾는 그런 게임같은데
처음 자기 방에 있는 피자상자에 굴러보기도 하고, 세이브 하면서 파랑색으로 염색되기도 하고, 놀이기구도 타고, 망망대해를 헤엄쳐보고, 기찻길 따라가다가 치이기도(?)하고, 대도시에서 신문배달(투척에 가깝지만) 아르바이트도 해보고, 시청에서 토론까지 해보는 등 소소한 재미를 느껴볼 수 있다.

맵도 자유롭게 돌아다닐 수 있다. 뭔가 중요한 일을 앞뒀을때 다른 컨텐츠를 즐긴다던지 하는 등, 보스전에 잠깐 막히는 것 빼고는 자유롭다.

밤과 낮이 존재하며 비가 오는 등 날씨효과도 존재하는데, 이 부분은 밤 시간대에 특정 퀘스트를 진행하는 것 빼곤 눈이 즐거운걸로 그치는 듯 하다.

그래픽은  전체적으로 (일단 귀엽고) 얼핏 보면 그림판으로 대충 그린거같지만, 플레이하다보면 의외로 세세한 느낌을 준다. 색감도 괜찮다.
브금도 잘 만들어졌다. 갠적으로 동굴파트랑, 블러저 한마리가 살고있는 곳이 제일 좋았다.

재미없으면 플탐 1시간도 못채우는게 다반사인데, 이건 정말 나를 새벽까지 하게 만들 정도로 빠져들게 했고, 몰입하면서 정말 재미있게 플레이 했다.

++ 최근 한글패치가 되어서, NPC들이 하는 말을 알아들을 수 있게 되었다.
번역해주신 분들께 감사드립니다!

25771398.review:
TL;DR: Labor of love, tailor-made charm, excellent action-puzzler platformer with a sense of childlike wonder.

Wuppo stars you as a fat little blob, exiled from your hometown for spilling ice cream across the floor. This frivolous beginning to the hero's journey conceals a deeper action puzzler experience -- like an archaeologist, your travels reveal the hidden history of your cute blobby civilization, from the ancient tribal wars to stone gods who came from the sky. Every screen of the game feels tailor-made, lending the game charm, style and storyline intrigue. Wuppo plays like a labor of love, resonating with the creator's admiration for the hand-crafted feel of similar style landmarks as Paper Mario. Particularly recommended for those who appreciate puzzles and platforming with a Nintendo charm.

25766253.review:
Wuppo's a very free-roamy game with cutesy art along with a very easygoing soundtrack. There are a variety of bosses and challenges packed inside the game waiting for you to face them.
I enjoyed collecting film strips and reading into the backstory of the world I was in (along with hilarious NPCs that threw their two cents in every now and again).

There are so many hidden secrets in this game, its almost impossible to find them all on your first playthrough. You can challenge yourself with INSANE mode, or just kick back during normal mode.
The enemies in the game aren't repetitive, and all the boss fights are pretty unique. You can tell the developers put a lot of hard work into this game.

You also have an insanely large inventory, so you'll most likely never run out of room during your adventures. With that, there are a good handful of hats to collect in the game to customize your character whenever you please.

The game's overall smooth controls make it very nice to move around in. (I often found myself jumping all over the place whenever I got the chance because it was honestly really satisfying seeing a little blob do sick backflips).
The game also pays attention to small details such as kicking rocks around as you walk past them, knocking over dishes if you jump around them, etc, so that's kind of a big deal.

One of my favorite parts of the game is Wonder Splenk. Its literally a theme park. You don't need to go there to progress through the story, however, there's no reason to pass it up. At Wonder Splenk, you can go on rides, get your fortune told, and play mini games. Be careful though; venture too far out into the sea and you'll be greeted by.. well, that's for you to find out. IF YOU DARE.

I would highly recommend this game to anyone that likes platformers, quirky stories, and / or challenging boss fights.
So take out your gumgum gun and get ready for a trilling adventure filled with Wums and other cute, small creatures!

25765815.review:
Do you like zany worlds, platforming while you puzzle, giant bosses [strike]and reviews that sound like advertisements[/strike]? Well, you might like Wuppo. 

Full disclosure; I have been given a key before the time of writing this review. However I can confidently say I've enjoyed my time with the game thusfar. What starts off as a silly plot about a Wum dirtying a hallway, quickly throws you into a world and quest bigger than yourself. A very charming world, I might add. From the angry desk manager Carlos to elevator boy to loudmouthed Denksnavel, the first minutes set a great atmosphere. Don't let it's cartoony silliness fool you, however, when it comes to the gameplay. Wuppo asks you to pay attention and a lot of it.

Exploration is a big part of Wuppo and it rarely outright states where you have to go next. It's story is a puzzle as much as individual sequences and boss fights can be. Wuppo has little intention of holding your hand and it will let you know. Early, frustratingly and brutally. Fortunately there are save points a plenty and the reward of solving a puzzle, beating a platforming section or wooping some boss ass is all very satisfying. Don't get discouraged by some of the harder or more hidden bits, it pays off in the end.

What I liked most about Wuppo is how it marries it's world and gameplay with it's overlapping atmosphere. There's a boss somewhere midway that the further down you get his health, the more you feel like bullying him than vice versa. There's a boss whose projectiles you have to get hit by just to survive, instilling a feeling of desperation. There's a part in the game that tells you to [i]get a job[/i]. It's filled with characters going about their lives, whose actions are just as important to the world as yours and individual NPCs their decisions are reflected in map and level design. All of this makes Wuppo, even with it's silly exterior, feel like a strongly immersive game. Just... Be ready to work for some of that experience.

Overall, if you like puzzle-platforming, possess the power of observation and enjoy a zany sense of humour, I think you'll enjoy getting lost in the world of Wuppo.
